repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
• 'null' values in LSP messages are now represented using |vim.NIL| instead of nil.
```
uh oh, looks like I made a typo here back in #34849

   message UI that mimics the legacy message grid. Benefit: reduced UI event
   traffic and more flexibility for UIs.
   The `msg_history_show` event has an additional "prev_cmd" argument.

-• `root_markers` in |vim.lsp.Config| can now be ordered by priority.
+• Missing fields in LSP messages are now represented using |vim.NIL| instead of nil.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
Besides creating |<Plug>| mappings, you may want to consider providing actions
by defining an in-process LSP "server". Offering actions as "code-actions"
```
To avoid repetitive usages of "define".

comment_data.body:
This will only work if there's a single code action provider using such code action title, and there's nothing in the protocol that would prevent 2 code action providers from using the same code action title.

This makes me realize that a code action should include its provider info (just as how diagnostics have a `source` field). I'll start a discussion around this.

+actions.

+Besides defining |<Plug>| mappings, you may want to consider providing actions
+by defining an in-process LSP "server". Defining actions as "code-actions"

+the default |gra| mapping to view the code-actions menu. They can even define
+mappings to a specific action by invoking `vim.lsp.buf.code_action()` with the
+`filter` + `apply` parameters: >lua

+    vim.lsp.buf.code_action({

comment_data.body: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/34383 was marked as breaking change, so I think we should keep it here.

Glad to get feedback on this. If anything is missing to support this idea then we definitely should figure out how to make it possible!

comment_data.body:
> Opened [microsoft/language-server-protocol#2188](https://github.com/microsoft/language-server-protocol/issues/2188)

Wasn't your original concern about the `filter` callback in `vim.lsp.buf.code_action`, which doesn't expose the client name?

I don't think it would make sense for a server to attach its name to every code action result - by the same logic, that field could be added to every response. For diagnostics, it can make sense to specify the linter or rule name, but I can't really imagine a case where a single LSP server provides multiple sources of code actions whose names would actually matter to the user.

I think we should just add `source` field with client name when passing `lsp.CodeAction` to `filter`, which we already compute when processing results to display in `gra` https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/53a4540047dbe6375c4658ca6ec8d4a092da9265/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/buf.lua#L1278

comment_data.body:
> a single LSP server provides multiple sources of code actions whose names would actually matter to the user.

A single LSP server would set the same `source` field in all of its code actions. Sure, I agree that we can just set that from the client, but having that information as part of the code action object feels valuable.

comment_data.body:
> A single LSP server would set the same `source` field in all of its code actions.

Why would it do that? The client knows which server sent the response anyway, and there's no real reason to include that in RPC messages. If there were one, it should apply to every response, not just diagnostics and code actions. Also, the existing source field in diagnostics isn't used that way.

I'm not against the LSP proposal itself, but I think it would help - both for me and for the LSP maintainers - to see a concrete example of what a server would actually want to put there.
